text: - My hair was my signature.

I walk into a room and
people notice my hair first.

I didn't have to say
anything or do anything.

KELLY BOWMAN: Dignicap was
created to help cancer patients

like Donna Tukes
minimize hair loss
while undergoing chemotherapy.

- In 1999, a Swedish oncology
nurse got a grant from

the Swedish federal
government to develop

a device-driven solution to
chemotherapy-induced alopecia.

The first device actually was
marketed outside the United
States by Dignitana in 2007.

KELLY BOWMAN: Dignicap was
approved by the FDA for use

in breast cancer patients
and solid tumor cancers.

It is being incorporated
into patient care
at facilities like Mount Sinai.

- There are other scalp
cooling techniques

that are a little more
laborious but have been
around in the US for a while.

Dignitana's system-- patient
does very little work.

A cap is applied initially
at room temperature, which

is attached to a cooling
hose, which is attached
to the machine next to them.

A second cap is then put on
for additional insulation.

And the patient
gets her treatment.

And over a course of hours,
the scalp is cooled down.

There are these sensors that
regulate keeping it that cold
and, therefore, more effect.
And then the patient goes home.

- The science
behind scalp cooling
is really rather simple.

By reducing a patient's
localized scalp temperature,

you constrict the
blood vessels, and that

impedes the flow of the
chemotherapeutic agents
to the hair follicles.

What chemo agents are
able to make their way

through the constricted
blood vessels,

then, are not actually
absorbed by the hair follicle.

And it enables the hair
follicle to escape the damage

that a normal
chemotherapy session
would inflict on your hair.

KELLY BOWMAN: Patients
receive the treatment

through the course of
their chemotherapy.

- We do hear from
many of our patients

that the decision to try to
keep their hair through chemo

is one of the few parts
of the process that's
actually under their control.

- The loss of control when
your health is in danger,

compromised, is probably one
of the worst aspects of it.

So you need to give them
a little piece of control.

DONNA TUKES: For
me, it was a gift.

This terrible thing
is happening to you.
These are all the side effects.

This is what you're
going to endure.

We're going to do the best
we can to save your life.

But in the meantime,
here's a gift.
KELLY BOWMAN: Kelly Bowman, CNN.
